interestingFacts.topic: I have decided to specialize in Ruby on Rails
interestingFacts.fact:
I have small projects in my Github on this technology, but nothing serious yet.
I have recently started a personal project that I am very excited about and with which I hope to learn as well as teach! I want to build a blog about Ruby on Rails in which I will upload articles and tutorials teaching (and at the same time learning more and more about the framework).

Luckily I have by my side a great friend who is a Senior Developer in Ruby on Rails, and he is guiding and helping me a lot!

I am totally committed to this goal, I want to work on Rails and get to mastery.

If I dont know something, I don't have any kind of problem with start learning something new!
I'm very self-taught.

details.name: BlogOnRails
details.description:
I will starting this week the project with my friend Eneko (RoR senior dev).

The main objective of this project is, first of all, to continue deepening in Ruby on Rails, and the workflow through GitHub.

We will do a simulation, Eneko will be the Product Manager and I will be the Junior Software Engineer. I think it's going to be great!

The project is based on building a blog 100% about RAILS where I will be able to upload useful articles about Ruby on Rails and news.
So, once the basic structure of the application is built, I will be able to add content that I have to research previously or things that I have just learned about the framework or web development in general.

Then, on each iteration, I will add more features like a forum, or private message system.

I will update the link to the project soon!!

details.name: Scheduled Tweets
details.description: In this application I am using Ruby on Rails and the Twitter API to build a web application that allows the user to have all their accounts (in case they have multiple accounts) in one place, and interact with them by scheduling the publication of tweets.

details.name: Airbnb clone
details.description:
Being able to see a professional web developer at work (without video cuts) is a very enriching process. I am following TypeFast project on Youtube, taking notes on everything that is new to me, and learning about the actual flow of development:

Have a problem --> Identify the source of the problem --> Know how to find information about the problem --> process the problem --> solve the problem.

(I'm learning A LOT, and i'm pretty happy!)
